Privacy Against Agnostic Inference Attacks in Vertical Federated Learning

Morteza Varasteh
School of Computer Science and Electronic Engineering, University of Essex, Colchester CO4 3SQ, UK
m.varasteh@essex.ac.uk
Abstract

A novel form of inference attack in vertical federated learning (VFL) is proposed, where two parties collaborate in training a machine learning (ML) model. Logistic regression is considered for the VFL model. One party, referred to as the active party, possesses the ground truth labels of the samples in the training phase, while the other, referred to as the passive party, only shares a separate set of features corresponding to these samples. It is shown that the active party can carry out inference attacks on both training and prediction phase samples by acquiring an ML model independently trained on the training samples available to them. This type of inference attack does not require the active party to be aware of the score of a specific sample, hence it is referred to as an agnostic inference attack. It is shown that utilizing the observed confidence scores during the prediction phase, before the time of the attack, can improve the performance of the active party’s autonomous model, and thus improve the quality of the agnostic inference attack. As a countermeasure, privacy-preserving schemes (PPSs) are proposed. While the proposed schemes preserve the utility of the VFL model, they systematically distort the VFL parameters corresponding to the passive party’s features. The level of the distortion imposed on the passive party’s parameters is adjustable, giving rise to a trade-off between privacy of the passive party and interpretabiliy of the VFL outcomes by the active party. The distortion level of the passive party’s parameters could be chosen carefully according to the privacy and interpretabiliy concerns of the passive and active parties, respectively, with the hope of keeping both parties (partially) satisfied. Finally, experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed attack and the PPSs.

I Introduction

The emergence of distributed machine learning (ML) techniques has been a game-changer in the way valuable information is obtained from raw data in various fields, such as computer vision, image recognition, financial services, and natural language processing. With the growing need for the utilization of distributed data to construct more accurate and advanced ML models, there has been a surge in demand in multiple sectors. To address the limitations of centralized ML models, including issues with data storage, excessive computations, security and privacy breaches, various distributed ML techniques have been proposed [1]. One such technique is federated learning (FL), which was introduced in [2]. In FL, two or more data-centers, known as parties, work together to train a shared ML model, thereby addressing the concerns of traditional centralized learning. This approach has gained widespread attention for its applications in real-life scenarios, such as in health systems [3, 4], keyboard prediction [5, 6], and e-commerce [7, 8].

Three types of Federated Learning (FL) are commonly studied in the literature, including Horizontal FL (HFL), Vertical FL (VFL), and Transfer FL. The distinction between these approaches lies in the manner in which data is partitioned and shared among parties. In HFL, each party holds a unique set of samples, but all parties share the same features [9]. On the other hand, VFL involves parties sharing the same samples, but each party trains and predicts collaboratively using a separate set of features [10]. As shown in Figure 1, an illustration of VFL is presented, where a bank and a FinTech company collaborate in training a classifier that will be used by the bank to approve or reject credit card applications. The bank, as the active party, holds the ground truth labels for the samples in the training set. Meanwhile, the FinTech company, as the passive party, contributes to the VFL process by sharing a distinct set of features pertaining to the samples.

After the VFL model is trained, both the bank and the FinTech company use it collaboratively to make predictions for new samples. To do this, each party inputs their corresponding features for each sample into the model. Typically, a third party known as the coordinator authority (CA) is involved in this collaboration during both the training and prediction phases. The CA’s role during the prediction phase is to obtain the model’s outcome for new samples and share it with the active party when requested. The model output can be in the form of a confidence score, which is a probability vector representing the likelihood of each class, or a one-hot vector representing the output class label. Due to privacy concerns, the confidence score of a sample may be distorted before it is delivered to the active party, typically by providing a noisy or rounded version of the score. In the literature generally two scenarios are considered for this type of collaboration, namely white box and black box settings, where the active party is aware and unaware of the passive party’s parameters, respectively.

Focusing on the prediction phase, in [11], it has been demonstrated that when the exact form of the confidence scores are shared with the active party, there is a risk of the adversary (i.e. the active party) reconstructing the features of the passive party, which are considered private information. This can result in a privacy leak for the users, and therefore known as inference attack. The reconstruction is accurate when the number of unknown features, or the passive party features, is less than the number of classes. In [12] various approaches regarding improved inference attacks have been proposed that are based on solving an under-determined system of linear equations. In particular, it is shown that using methods that approximate the best worst case solution among feasible solutions can significantly improve the attack accuracy. Furthermore, as a defense mechanism, it has been shown in [12] that by transforming the passive features111For brevity, throughout the paper we use passive (active) features and passive (active) parameters instead of passive (active) party’s features and passive (active) party’s parameters, respectively. in a linear fashion and keeping the transformation mapping hidden from the active party, it is possible to preserve the model’s accuracy while reducing the privacy leakage, (i.e., higher mean squared error in reconstructing the passive features).

While previous works have studied inference attacks in the prediction phase using samples whose confidence scores (or a different version of them) are available at the active party, in this paper, under the white box setting, we focus on the privacy leakage of samples whose confidence scores are not yet available at the active party. This can include samples in the prediction phase for which no score has been requested by the active party, as well as samples used in the training phase to train the VFL model. Since the adversary is unaware of the confidence score of the attack target, we refer to this type of attack as an agnostic inference attack. Focusing on this type of privacy leakage, the main contributions of the paper are as follows.

  • •

    The active party uses its available resources, i.e., the training data with only the active features, to reconstruct an independent classifier similar to the VFL model. This classifier is named the adversary model (AM). This is possible because the active party already has access to the ground truth labels of samples in the training set. The AM can be used for two purposes. First, as a means to estimate any sample’s confidence score and conduct inference attacks on the passive features using the methods introduced in [12]. The main aspect of this type of attack is that the adversary is agnostic to the confidence score or any other form of it corresponding to the attack target, hence putting all the training samples at risk of privacy leakage as well. Second, by comparing the sample-by-sample scores obtained from the AM and VFL model during the prediction phase, the active party can use the amount of score mismatch as a measure of the improvement in classification due to the VFL and decide whether to continue or stop requesting further collaborative predictions. This is particularly useful when the active party incurs a cost for each VFL model prediction made through CA.

  • •

    Although the AM is primarily trained on the training samples, its ability to conduct an attack can be enhanced by taking into account the prediction samples and their associated confidence scores that have already been communicated to the active party. We consider two scenarios for delivering confidence scores: when they are delivered in their exact form and when their corresponding class labels are delivered to the active party. It is observed that incorporating both the confidence scores and their corresponding class labels leads to significant and subtle improvements in the effectiveness of an attack, respectively. Observing that any any other forms222Note that by “any other form”, we mean those which do not affect the accuracy. of confidence scores, such as noisy or rounded scores, can be transformed into their corresponding class labels and utilized in the training of the AM highlights the inadequacy of privacy-preserving schemes (PPSs) that only focus on protecting the confidence scores. This realization prompts a reconsideration of PPSs in the context of VFL, with the main focus on the model parameters rather than the confidence scores, which departs from black and white views in VFL settings.

  • •

    We propose PPSs as a defense mechanism against agnostic inference attacks. The proposed schemes are designed to maintain the utility of the VFL model, i.e., delivering confidence scores in their exact form, while at the same time preventing adversaries from misusing the VFL collaboration. To that end, we design algorithms in a case-by-case fashion, where the parameters corresponding to passive features are distorted. The level of distortion applied to passive parameters is variable and determines the degree of privacy leakage of the passive party. That is, a higher level of distortion applied to passive parameters results in a lower degree of privacy compromise. This creates a trade-off between interpretability of the VFL parameters/outcomes by the active party and privacy concerns of the passive party. To address the privacy-interpretability (PI) trade-off, we aim to find a balance that satisfies the needs of both parties to the greatest extent possible, rather than completely shielding the passive party from view or completely obscuring the active party’s understanding of the parameters. Our goal is to strike a balance between these two competing demands and find a solution that partially meets the needs of both parties

The paper is structured as follows. In Section II, an explanation of the system model under study is provided. In Section III, the characteristics of the datasets utilized in this paper, as well as the model used for evaluating the results, are reviewed. Section IV is dedicated to the introduction of agnostic inference attack and is divided into three sub-sections. In Section IV-A, the necessary background information required to perform an inference attack is discussed. Subsequently, in Section IV-B, the procedure for obtaining and refining the AM is detailed, followed by a performance analysis of agnostic inference attack in Section IV-C. The proposed PPSs against agnostic inference attack are described in detail in Section V, which is further divided into two sub-sections. In Section V-A, the geometry of optimization algorithms with orthogonality constraints, specifically optimization over Stiefel manifolds, is reviewed to provide a better understanding of one of the proposed PPSs. Additionally, an overview of the concept of interpretability in the context of the present work is also provided. In Section V-B, the technical analysis of the proposed PPSs is presented. In Section VI, the experimental results are reported and discussed, along with a comprehensive evaluation of the performance of agnostic inference attack on real-world datasets under various scenarios and the performance of the proposed PPSs. The paper concludes in Section VII.

II System model

II-A Machine learning (ML)

An ML model is a function f𝜽:𝒳→𝒰:subscript𝑓𝜽→𝒳𝒰f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}:\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{U} parameterized by the vector 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}, where 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} denote the input and output spaces, respectively. In this paper, we consider the supervised classification setting, where a labeled training dataset is used to train the model.

Assume that a training dataset 𝒟train≜{(𝐱i,ui)|i∈[n]}≜subscript𝒟trainconditional-setsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\mathcal{D}_{\textnormal{train}}\triangleq\{(\mathbf{x}_{i},u_{i})|i\in[n]\} is given, where each 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} is a dtsubscript𝑑𝑡d_{t}-dimensional example/sample and uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} denotes its corresponding label. Learning refers to the process of obtaining the parameter vector 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} in the minimization of a loss function, i.e.,

min𝜽⁡1n​∑i=1nl​(f𝜽​(𝐱i),ui)+ω​(𝜽),subscript𝜽1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑙subscript𝑓𝜽subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖𝜔𝜽\min_{\mathbf{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}l(f_{\mathbf{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}(\mathbf{x}_{i}),u_{i})+\omega(\mathbf{\boldsymbol{\theta}}), (1)

where l​(⋅,⋅)𝑙⋅⋅l(\cdot,\cdot) measures the prediction loss of f𝜽​(𝐱i)subscript𝑓𝜽subscript𝐱𝑖f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\mathbf{x}_{i}), while the true label is ui,i∈[n]subscript𝑢𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛u_{i},i\in[n]. To avoid overfitting, a regularization term ω​(𝜽)𝜔𝜽\omega(\boldsymbol{\theta}) can be added to the optimization.

Once the model is trained, i.e., 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} is obtained, it can be used for the prediction of any new sample. In practice, the prediction is a (probability) vector-valued, i.e., it is a vector of confidence scores as 𝐜=(c1,c2,…,ck)T𝐜superscriptsubscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2…subscript𝑐𝑘𝑇\mathbf{c}=(c_{1},c_{2},\ldots,c_{k})^{T} with ∑jcj=1,cj≥0,j∈[k]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑗subscript𝑐𝑗1formulae-sequencesubscript𝑐𝑗0𝑗delimited-[]𝑘\sum_{j}c_{j}=1,c_{j}\geq 0,j\in[k], where cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j} denotes the probability that the sample belongs to class j𝑗j, and k𝑘k denotes the number of classes. Classification can be done by choosing the class that has the highest probability.

II-B Vertical Federated Learning

VFL is a type of distributive ML model training approach in which two or more parties are involved in the training process, such that they hold the same set of samples with disjoint set of features. The main goal in VFL is to train a model in a privacy-preserving manner, i.e., to collaboratively train a model without each party having access to other parties’ features. Typically, the training involves a trusted third party known as the CA, and it is commonly assumed that only one party has access to the label information in the training and testing datasets. This party is named active and the remaining parties are called passive. Throughout this paper, we assume that only two parties are involved; one is active and the other is passive. The active party is assumed to be honest but curious, i.e., it obeys the protocols exactly, but may try to infer passive features based on the information received. As a result, the active party is exchangeably referred to as the adversary in this paper.

In the existing VFL frameworks, CA’s main task is to coordinate the learning process once it has been initiated by the active party. During the training, CA receives the intermediate model updates from each party, and after a set of computations, backpropagates each party’s gradient updates, separately and securely. To meet the privacy requirements of parties’ datasets, cryptographic techniques such as secure multi-party computation (SMC) [13] or homomorphic encryption (HE) [14] are used.

Once the global model is trained, upon the request of the active party for a new record prediction, each party computes the results of their model using their own features. CA aggregates these results from all the parties, obtains the prediction vector (confidence scores), and delivers that to the active party for further action. Throughout this paper, we assume that the active party is not allowed to make any query about the scores of the samples in the training set. This is justified due to the fact that the active party already has the ground truth labels of the training set. Note that there could be some edge cases where confidence scores of all the samples (both in the training and prediction phases) are required, such as when the active party aims at forming a soft clustering among all the samples via Gaussian mixture model to determine a high-confidence region within each class666For instance, in the Bank-FinTech example, the bank may wish to grant credit approval for clients with low entropy confidence scores due to budget limitations.. Where this is the case, i.e., exact or distorted versions of attack targets’ scores are available at the active party, inference attack methods studied in [12] could be applied to reconstruct the passive features.

As in [11, 12], we assume that the active party has no information whatsoever about the underlying distribution of passive features. However, it is assumed that the knowledge about the names, types and ranges of passive features is available to the active party to decide whether to participate in a VFL or not.

III Datasets and model

Datasets. In this paper, we perform a comprehensive evaluation of our proposed methods on five real-world and publicly available datasets, namely Bank, Adult salaries, Pen-based handwriting digits, Electrical grid stability and Satellite. These datasets have been widely used in the literature and have been obtained from the Machine Learning Repository website [15]. They have been selected to cover a wide range of classification tasks, including both binary and multi-class classification. The details of each of these datasets are provided in Table I. Furthermore, to gain further insights into the characteristics of these datasets, we provide a visual representation of some of their empirical statistics in Figure 3.

In the Bank dataset, there are a total of 20 features. However, as stated in the dataset’s description file on the Machine Learning Repository website [15], the 11th feature has a significant impact on the output target and should be disregarded in order to obtain a more accurate predictive model. As a result, the training process in our study is based on 19 features, as detailed in Table I. Additionally, this dataset has 10 categorical features which need to be handled properly by the predictive model. Common ways to do this include one-hot encoding of the categorical features, mapping ordinal values to each category, mapping categorical values to theirs statistics, and so on. In this paper, we have chosen to map each categorical feature to its average within each class. This approach has been found to be effective for models such as Logistic Regression (LR) and Neural Networks (NN).

In our selection of datasets for the purpose of classification, we have considered a number of key factors. Firstly, it is crucial that the LR model performs reasonably well on the chosen dataset. Here, we have chosen the minimum 85% test accuracy as a threshold below which a dataset is discarded from the experiments. This is essential as any less reliable confidence scores produced by the LR model would make it difficult to demonstrate the impact of the agnostic inference attack. Secondly, it is necessary that each feature in the dataset contributes significantly to the training of the VFL model. If not, the matrices 𝕎actsubscript𝕎act\mathbb{W}_{\text{act}} and 𝕎passubscript𝕎pas\mathbb{W}_{\text{pas}} may contain small numbers associated with those features, leading to errors in the machine’s calculations. This was avoided in our experiments by utilizing feature importance calculation methods. Thirdly, the dataset chosen should not have a diagonal covariance matrix associated to its features. As will be explained later, an agnostic inference attack on datasets with a diagonal covariance matrix does not result in a substantial breach of privacy. To further emphasize this point, we have included the Grid dataset as an example, in which we provide a clear explanation of why this type of attack is not effective on these types of datasets.

Model. In this paper, we focus on LR, which can be modelled as

𝐜=σ​(𝐖𝐱+𝐛),𝐜𝜎𝐖𝐱𝐛\displaystyle\mathbf{c}=\sigma(\mathbf{Wx}+\mathbf{b}), (2)

where 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} and 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} are the parameters collectively denoted as 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}, and σ​(⋅)𝜎⋅\sigma(\cdot) is the sigmoid or softmax function in the case of binary or multi-class classification, respectively. Each party holds their parameters corresponding to their local features. The VFL model is trained in a centralized manner, which is a reasonable assumption according to [11]. It is assumed that no intermediate information is revealed during the training phase, and only the final model is disclosed.

As in [11], the feature values in each dataset are normalized into [0,1]01[0,1]. It is important to note that normalizing the entire dataset, including both the training and test data, may lead to an overly optimistic model accuracy, a phenomenon known as data snooping [16]. This effect occurs when working with very noisy datasets and should be avoided in such cases. However, in our experiments, we have not considered this issue as the datasets under consideration are not excessively noisy.

Each dataset has been divided into 80% training data and 20% prediction data. The training set which is the one used for VFL model training is again split into 80% training and 20% test data. Data splitting is done using train__\_test__\_split in the scikit-learn package. In training LR, we apply early stopping, and the training is done without considering any regularization. ADAM optimization is used for training, and the codes, which are in PyTorch, are available online in our GitHub repository [17].

Baselines. Depending on the number of unknown features compared to the number of classes in a dataset, two different scenarios are considered. To approach these cases we use two different inference attack (estimation) methods, namely the least square and half∗ methods. The latter is proposed in [12] which is also briefly explained in section IV-A.

IV Agnostic Inference Attack

IV-A Preliminaries

Let (𝐘T,𝐗T)Tsuperscriptsuperscript𝐘𝑇superscript𝐗𝑇𝑇(\mathbf{Y}^{T},\mathbf{X}^{T})^{T} denote random dtsubscript𝑑𝑡d_{t}-dimensional input samples, where the (dt−d)subscript𝑑𝑡𝑑(d_{t}-d)-dimensional 𝐘𝐘\mathbf{Y}, and the d𝑑d-dimensional 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, correspond to the feature values held by the active and passive parties, respectively. We denote the samples in the training and prediction phase by the subscripts t and p, respectively, e.g., 𝐗psubscript𝐗𝑝\mathbf{X}_{p} represents the features of a samples in the prediction phase held by the passive party777When no distinction is required, we use the generic forms 𝐘,𝐗𝐘𝐗\mathbf{Y},\mathbf{X}..

The VFL model under consideration is LR, where the confidence score is given by 𝐜=σ​(𝐳)𝐜𝜎𝐳\mathbf{c}=\sigma(\mathbf{z}) with 𝐳=𝕎act​𝐘+𝕎pas​𝐗+𝐛𝐳subscript𝕎act𝐘subscript𝕎pas𝐗𝐛\mathbf{z}=\mathbb{W}_{\textnormal{act}}\mathbf{Y}+\mathbb{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{b}. Denoting the number of classes in the classification task by k𝑘k, 𝕎actsubscript𝕎act\mathbb{W}_{\textnormal{act}} (with dimension k×(dt−d)𝑘subscript𝑑𝑡𝑑k\times(d_{t}-d)) and 𝕎passubscript𝕎pas\mathbb{W}_{\textnormal{pas}} (with dimension k×d𝑘𝑑k\times d) are the model parameters of the active and passive parties, respectively, and 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} is the k𝑘k-dimensional bias vector. From the definition of σ​(⋅)𝜎⋅\sigma(\cdot), we have

ln⁡cm+1cm=zm+1−zm,m∈[k−1],formulae-sequencesubscript𝑐𝑚1subscript𝑐𝑚subscript𝑧𝑚1subscript𝑧𝑚𝑚delimited-[]𝑘1\displaystyle\ln\frac{c_{m+1}}{c_{m}}=z_{m+1}-z_{m},\ m\in[k-1], (3)

where cm,zmsubscript𝑐𝑚subscript𝑧𝑚c_{m},z_{m} denote the m𝑚m-th component of 𝐜,𝐳𝐜𝐳\mathbf{c},\mathbf{z}, respectively. Define 𝐉𝐉\mathbf{J} as

𝐉≜[−1100…00−110…000−11…0⋮⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮0……0−11](k−1)×k,≜𝐉subscriptmatrix1100…00110…00011…0⋮⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮0……011𝑘1𝑘\mathbf{J}\triangleq\begin{bmatrix}-1&1&0&0&\ldots&0\\ 0&-1&1&0&\ldots&0\\ 0&0&-1&1&\ldots&0\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ 0&\ldots&\ldots&0&-1&1\end{bmatrix}_{(k-1)\times k}, (4)

whose rows are cyclic permutations of the first row with offset equal to the row index−11-1. By multiplying both sides of 𝐳=𝕎act​𝕐+𝕎pas​𝕏+𝕓𝐳subscript𝕎act𝕐subscript𝕎pas𝕏𝕓\mathbf{z}=\mathbb{W}_{\textnormal{act}}\mathbb{Y}+\mathbb{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}\mathbb{X}+\mathbb{b} with 𝐉𝐉\mathbf{J}, and using (3), we get

=𝐜′−𝕁​𝕎act​𝐘−𝐉𝐛,absentsuperscript𝐜′𝕁subscript𝕎act𝐘𝐉𝐛\displaystyle=\mathbf{c}^{\prime}-\mathbb{J}\mathbb{W}_{\textnormal{act}}\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{Jb}, (6)

where 𝐜′superscript𝐜′\mathbf{c}^{\prime} is a (k−1)𝑘1(k-1)-dimensional vector whose m𝑚m-th component is ln⁡cm+1cmsubscript𝑐𝑚1subscript𝑐𝑚\ln\frac{c_{m+1}}{c_{m}}. Denoting the RHS of (6) by 𝕓′superscript𝕓′\mathbb{b}^{\prime}, (6) writes in short as 𝐀𝐱=𝐛′𝐀𝐱superscript𝐛′\mathbf{Ax}=\mathbf{b}^{\prime}, where 𝐀≜𝕁​𝕎pas≜𝐀𝕁subscript𝕎pas\mathbf{A}\triangleq\mathbb{JW}_{\textnormal{pas}}.

The white-box setting refers to the scenario where the adversary is aware of (𝐖act,𝐖pas,𝐛)subscript𝐖actsubscript𝐖pas𝐛(\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{act}},\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}},\mathbf{b}) and the black-box setting refers to the context in which the adversary is only aware of 𝐖actsubscript𝐖act\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{act}}. In this paper, we are interested in a scenario where the active party wishes to reconstruct passive features of samples whose confidence scores 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} have not been observed yet (which encompasses all the samples in the training phase as well). One measure by which the attack performance can be evaluated is the mean squared error per feature, i.e.,

MSE=1d​𝔼​[‖𝐗−𝐗^‖2],MSE1𝑑𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐗^𝐗2\textnormal{MSE}=\frac{1}{d}\mathds{E}\left[\|\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}\|^{2}\right], (7)

where 𝐗^^𝐗\hat{\mathbf{X}} is the adversary’s estimate. Let N𝑁N denote the number of samples whose passive features have been estimated. Assuming that these N𝑁N samples are produced in an i.i.d. manner, Law of Large Numbers (LLN) allows to approximate MSE by its empirical value 1N​d​∑i=1N‖𝐗i−𝐗i^‖21𝑁𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptnormsubscript𝐗𝑖^subscript𝐗𝑖2\frac{1}{Nd}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\mathbf{X}_{i}-\hat{\mathbf{X}_{i}}\|^{2}, since the latter converges almost surely to (7) as N𝑁N grows.

IV-B Adversary Model (AM)

Recall that we study a scenario where prediction scores (exact forms or other) of attack targets are not available at the active party. When evaluating the potential inference attacks within this context, it is important to consider the passive party’s vulnerabilities due to not just the white box setting, but also the availability of data to the active party. This aspect of the scenario (the active party’s data) is often overlooked or underestimated in the related literature, but it can play a significant role in the success or failure of an attack. The active party’s access to data and the quality of that data can greatly impact their ability to carry out an effective inference attack. Despite the limitations imposed by the lack of access to prediction scores, the active party can still utilize the data and resources available to them to conduct an inference attack on passive features during both the training and prediction phases. To achieve this, the active party can build an independent AM using the training data at their disposal. This allows the active party to estimate the confidence scores of their target, empowering them to carry out a successful attack. To build an AM, the active party trains a classifier, denoted by f𝜽a:𝒴→𝒰:subscript𝑓subscript𝜽𝑎→𝒴𝒰f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}}:\mathcal{Y}\to\mathcal{U}, using only the active features, independently of the passive party and CA. This is feasible as the active party already has the ground truth labels for their training set. The parameters of the AM are obtained through a training process applied over the active party’s dataset, via the following minimization

min𝜽a⁡1nt​∑i=1ntH​(f𝜽a​(𝐲t,i),ui)+ω​(𝜽a),subscriptsubscript𝜽𝑎1subscript𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑡𝐻subscript𝑓subscript𝜽𝑎subscript𝐲𝑡𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖𝜔subscript𝜽𝑎\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}}\frac{1}{n_{t}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{t}}H(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}),u_{i})+\omega(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}), (8)

where ntsubscript𝑛𝑡n_{t} is the number of training samples, and 𝐲t,isubscript𝐲𝑡𝑖\mathbf{y}_{t,i} is the active features of the i𝑖i-th sample in the training set.

Training an independent classifier by the active party may appear to be a useful method to evaluate the improvement in performance due to collaboration with the passive party when building the VFL model. However, this approach can also be used for malicious purposes. For example, the active party can use f𝜽asubscript𝑓subscript𝜽𝑎f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}} to estimate confidence scores, denoted by 𝐜^^𝐜\hat{\mathbf{c}}, without even making a prediction query from CA. These estimates can then be used to conduct inference attacks on passive features of any training or unseen sample. This can be achieved by forming a new set of equations using the steps outlined in (3) to (6), with 𝐜𝐜\mathbf{c} being replaced with 𝐜^^𝐜\hat{\mathbf{c}}. As discussed in further detail in section IV-C, with this new set of equations, the adversary can use known methods for inference attacks [12] to estimate the passive features. Needless to say that this puts all samples in the training set and samples whose scores have yet to be observed at risk of privacy breaches.

Postponing the technical analysis to section IV-C, in Figure 3 the performance of agnostic inference attack (solid line) on the bank dataset is compared with two other baselines, namely the half (green solid++ line) and half∗ (blue solid∙∙\bullet line) estimations. In the former, the passive features are estimated as half (recall that features are normalized into [0,1]01[0,1]). In the latter, the half∗ estimation method, proposed in [12], is used. As it is observed from the results in Figure 3, even in the absence of targets’ confidence scores, the adversary manages to conduct an inference attack comparably well, especially for larger values of d𝑑d where the difference with the normal inference attack is negligible.

IV-B1 Refined AM

To further enhance the accuracy of the AM in estimating the targets’ confidence scores, the active party can leverage the prediction scores received from CA before carrying out an inference attack on a specific target. These scores are generated by applying the VFL model that has been trained on the combination of both active and passive features. As a result, they carry a higher level of confidence compared to the scores generated from f𝜽asubscript𝑓subscript𝜽𝑎f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}}. To take advantage of this increased reliability, the active party could adopt a training approach where the objective loss function incorporates the scores received from the CA. This can be done in a way that during the AM training, a higher cost is incurred in the event of a mismatch between the refined AM’s scores and the scores received from CA.

We study two cases for this scenario: case i) when the confidence scores are delivered to the active party in their exact form, and case ii) when the class labels corresponding to the scores are provided instead. It’s important to note that as long as the delivered scores retain their accuracy, (at the very least) they can be converted into their corresponding class labels and utilized for refining the AM. Our experimental results indicate that refining the AM via confidence scores and class labels leads to pronounced and subtle improvement of an attack performance by the active party, respectively.

The refined AM, denoted as f𝜽arsubscript𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑎𝑟f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}}, is trained on the active party’s available data by solving the following optimization problem

min𝜽arsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑎𝑟\displaystyle\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}}\ \ 1nt+np​(∑i=1ntH​(f𝜽ar​(𝐲t,i),ut,i)+β​∑j=1npH​(f𝜽ar​(𝐲p,j),up,j))1subscript𝑛𝑡subscript𝑛𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑡𝐻subscript𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑎𝑟subscript𝐲𝑡𝑖subscript𝑢𝑡𝑖𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑝𝐻subscript𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑎𝑟subscript𝐲𝑝𝑗subscript𝑢𝑝𝑗\displaystyle\frac{1}{n_{t}+n_{p}}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n_{t}}H(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}}(\mathbf{y}_{t,i}),u_{t,i})+\beta\sum_{j=1}^{n_{p}}H(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}}(\mathbf{y}_{p,j}),u_{p,j})\right)
+αnp​∑j=1npS​(f𝜽ar​(𝐲p,j),𝐜j)+ω​(𝜽ar)𝛼subscript𝑛𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑛𝑝𝑆subscript𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑎𝑟subscript𝐲𝑝𝑗subscript𝐜𝑗𝜔superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑎𝑟\displaystyle+\frac{\alpha}{n_{p}}\sum_{j=1}^{n_{p}}S\left(f_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}}(\mathbf{y}_{p,j}),\mathbf{c}_{j}\right)+\omega(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{a}^{r}) (9)

where npsubscript𝑛𝑝n_{p} denotes the total number of prediction samples (whose scores have already been delivered to the active party). The hyperparameters α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta are used to stress the level of reliability of the prediction scores and the class labels, respectively obtained from CA as compared to the ones obtained by feeding the corresponding active features into AM. Additionally, the scoring function, S​(x,y)𝑆𝑥𝑦S(x,y), is defined as log2⁡(x/y)superscript2𝑥𝑦{\log^{2}(x/y)}.

Remark 1.

It is noted that when there is no prediction score available, the objective function in (IV-B1) is essentially the same as the one in (8). In scenarios where CA provides confidence scores in their exact form, the values of the hyperparameters (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta) are set to (1,0)10(1,0). This is because in this scenario, it is deemed unnecessary to utilize both the confidence scores and the corresponding class labels as the latter can be derived from the former. On the other hand, when only the class labels are utilized for refining AM, (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta) is set to (0,1)01(0,1). This is simply due to the unavailability of confidence scores at the active party in this case.

Remark 2.

The choice of the function S​(⋅,⋅)𝑆⋅⋅S(\cdot,\cdot) in equation (IV-B1) is motivated by the desire to model the similarity (or soft mismatch) between the confidence scores delivered by CA and the ones produced by AM. The function S​(x,y)𝑆𝑥𝑦S(x,y) is a quasiconvex888This function is not convex as, however, it is quasi-convex. A function is quasi-convex if its lower level sets are convex. function that attains its minimum value of zero when x=y𝑥𝑦x=y. By setting α≥1𝛼1\alpha\geq 1, one can adjust the significance of samples during the prediction phase. This is essentially equivalent to enforce AM to overfit over the prediction confidence scores received from CA.

Remark 3.

The values of the hyperparameters α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta in equation (IV-B1) must be determined by the active party without knowledge of the actual values of the passive features. Determining the optimal values of these hyperparameters requires a significant amount of numerical experimentation on a diverse range of data, and would require a substantial effort to reach a consensus through experimentation. We leave the further exploration of this matter to interested parties.

IV-C Performance Analysis

Upon agreement on a trained VFL model, during the prediction phase, the active party receives the corresponding confidence score (or a modified version of it, such as a noisy or rounded version, or the corresponding class label). In the white-box setting, the active party can construct a system of linear equations as described in equation (6), where the unknown variables are the passive features. If the number of unknowns, d𝑑d, is equal to or less than the number of equations, k−1𝑘1k-1, and the confidence scores are provided in their exact form, the active party can recover the passive features by solving the linear system, 𝐀𝐗=𝐛′𝐀𝐗superscript𝐛′\mathbf{A}\mathbf{X}=\mathbf{b}^{\prime}. However, if the confidence scores have been altered to satisfy privacy requirements, or if the number of unknowns, d𝑑d, is greater than the number of equations, k−1𝑘1k-1, causing 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} to not have full column rank, there may exist either a different solution or an infinite number of solutions for the linear system, respectively.

A closer examination of (6) poses the following question: In a white box setting, to what extent does the lack of confidence scores from the attack targets contribute to the average reconstruction error in (7)? Or equivalently, can an inference attack still be performed effectively in the absence of the actual confidence score? In order to answer these questions, we will evaluate the performance of an attack when an estimate of a confidence score obtained from AM is used instead of the actual value. We will consider two scenarios: i) d<k𝑑𝑘d<k, and ii) d≥k𝑑𝑘d\geq k. These scenarios will be analyzed in detail to gain a better understanding of the impact of the absence of confidence scores.

IV-C1 d<k𝑑𝑘d<k

In this case, we have an overdetermined system of linear equations, i.e., we have more equations (k−1𝑘1k-1) than unknowns (d𝑑d). An overdetermined system can have solutions in some cases, e.g., when some equations are linear combinations of others. In the context of this paper, an example of an overdetermined system with a unique solution is when the active party have all the ingredients needed to solve (6). In this case, no matter which d𝑑d equations are chosen out of k−1𝑘1k-1, it yields the same solution. However, depending on how many of the equations are independent of each other, we can have other cases with no solution or infinite solutions. The case of interest where the active party do not have the attack target’s confidence score, is an example of an overdetermined system with no solution. In this case, approximate solutions can be obtained via the method of ordinary least squares, i.e., min𝐗⁡‖𝐀𝐗−𝐛′^‖subscript𝐗norm𝐀𝐗^superscript𝐛′\min_{\mathbf{X}}\|\mathbf{AX}-\hat{\mathbf{b}^{\prime}}\|, the solution of which can be written with the normal equations as999Throughout the paper, 𝐜^′superscript^𝐜′\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime} is adversary’s estimation of 𝐜′superscript𝐜′\mathbf{c}^{\prime}, and accordingly, 𝐛^′superscript^𝐛′\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\prime} is an approximation of 𝐛′superscript𝐛′\mathbf{b}^{\prime} induced by 𝐜^′superscript^𝐜′\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}.

𝐗^LS=(𝐀T​𝐀)−1​𝐀T​𝐛^′.subscript^𝐗LSsuperscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇𝐀1superscript𝐀𝑇superscript^𝐛′\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS}}=(\mathbf{A}^{T}\mathbf{A})^{-1}\mathbf{A}^{T}\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\prime}. (10)

With (10), an approximate solution is found when no exact solution exists (𝐛^′≠𝐛′superscript^𝐛′superscript𝐛′\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\prime}\neq\mathbf{b}^{\prime}), and it gives an exact solution when one does exist101010To achieve good numerical accuracy, using QR factorization is recommended. In this paper, we use (10) in our technical analysis due to the analytical tractability of this solution. However, to obtain the numerical results we use QR factorization. (i.e., when 𝐛^′=𝐛′superscript^𝐛′superscript𝐛′\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\prime}=\mathbf{b}^{\prime}).

Assuming that the adversary has a confidence score, denoted by 𝐜^′superscript^𝐜′\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}, different from the one in equation (6), an approximate solution denoted by 𝐗^LS,asubscript^𝐗LS𝑎\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS},a} is obtained as below111111Throughout the paper, subscript a𝑎a in estimations such as X^LS,asubscript^XLS𝑎\hat{\textnormal{X}}_{\textnormal{LS},a} is used to emphasize that the attack is agnostic.

𝐗^LS,asubscript^𝐗LS𝑎\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS},a} =(𝐀T​𝐀)−1​𝐀T​(𝐜^′−𝕁​𝕎act​𝐘−𝐉𝐛)absentsuperscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇𝐀1superscript𝐀𝑇superscript^𝐜′𝕁subscript𝕎act𝐘𝐉𝐛\displaystyle=(\mathbf{A}^{T}\mathbf{A})^{-1}\mathbf{A}^{T}(\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}-\mathbb{J}\mathbb{W}_{\textnormal{act}}\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{Jb}) (11)
=(𝐀T​𝐀)−1​𝐀T​(𝐛′+𝐜^′−𝐜′).absentsuperscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇𝐀1superscript𝐀𝑇superscript𝐛′superscript^𝐜′superscript𝐜′\displaystyle=(\mathbf{A}^{T}\mathbf{A})^{-1}\mathbf{A}^{T}(\mathbf{b}^{\prime}+\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}-\mathbf{c}^{\prime}). (12)

The MSE of this estimation reads as

MSE​(𝐗^LS,a)MSEsubscript^𝐗LS𝑎\displaystyle\textnormal{MSE}(\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS},a}) =1d​𝔼​[‖𝐗−𝐗^LS,a‖2]absent1𝑑𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐗subscript^𝐗LS𝑎2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{d}\mathds{E}\left[\|\mathbf{X}-\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{LS},a}\|^{2}\right]
=1d​𝔼​[‖𝐗−(𝐀T​𝐀)−1​𝐀T​(𝐛′+𝐜^′−𝐜′)‖2]absent1𝑑𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐗superscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇𝐀1superscript𝐀𝑇superscript𝐛′superscript^𝐜′superscript𝐜′2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{d}\mathds{E}\left[\|\mathbf{X}-(\mathbf{A}^{T}\mathbf{A})^{-1}\mathbf{A}^{T}(\mathbf{b}^{\prime}+\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}-\mathbf{c}^{\prime})\|^{2}\right]

where 𝐊𝐜′,𝐜^′≜𝔼​[(𝐜^′−𝐜′)​(𝐜^′−𝐜′)T]≜subscript𝐊superscript𝐜′superscript^𝐜′𝔼delimited-[]superscript^𝐜′superscript𝐜′superscriptsuperscript^𝐜′superscript𝐜′𝑇\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{c}^{\prime},\mathbf{\hat{c}}^{\prime}}\triangleq\mathds{E}[(\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}-\mathbf{c}^{\prime})(\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}-\mathbf{c}^{\prime})^{T}]. From (13), it is easy to note that when the active party have the exact form of the scores, the MSE in this case is zero, i.e., perfect reconstruction. Additionally, note that (13) is non-negative due to the non-negativity of MSE.

IV-C2 d≥k𝑑𝑘d\geq k

In the study presented in [12], several inference attack methods were evaluated, including RCC1, RCC2, CLS, and half∗. These methods were found to significantly improve the adversary’s estimation quality, resulting in lower MSE compared to the methods discussed in [11, 18]. While the results and discussions for agnostic inference attack in this paper are general and apply to any of the feature estimation methods, for the purposes of this paper, we specifically focus on using the half∗ method. This is because, on the one hand, the half∗ method is analytically feasible, making it easier to study. On the other hand, as indicated in [12, Figure 4], the half∗ reconstruction method was found to have the best performance, or at least performance comparable to the best method. Thus, before proceeding with our analysis, we briefly outline the half∗ estimation method.

Any solution of an underdetermined system of linear equations (d≥k𝑑𝑘d\geq k) can be written as 𝐀+​𝐛′+(𝐈d−𝐀+​𝐀)​𝐰superscript𝐀superscript𝐛′subscript𝐈𝑑superscript𝐀𝐀𝐰\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}^{\prime}+(\mathbf{I}_{d}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})\mathbf{w} for some 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where 𝐀+superscript𝐀\mathbf{A}^{+} denotes the pseudoinverse of 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} satisfying the Moore-Penrose conditions[19]121212When 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A} has linearly independent rows, we have 𝐀+=𝐀T​(𝐀𝐀T)−1superscript𝐀superscript𝐀𝑇superscriptsuperscript𝐀𝐀𝑇1\mathbf{A}^{+}=\mathbf{A}^{T}(\mathbf{AA}^{T})^{-1}.. As elaborated further in [12], when the only available information about 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X} is that it belongs to [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d}, then 𝐗^half=12​𝟏dsubscript^𝐗half12subscript1𝑑\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}}=\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d} is optimal in the best-worst sense. Indeed, the naive estimate of 12​𝟏d12subscript1𝑑\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d}, is the Chebyshev center of [0,1]dsuperscript01𝑑[0,1]^{d}. The adversary can perform better when the side information (𝐛′,𝐀)superscript𝐛′𝐀(\mathbf{b}^{\prime},\mathbf{A}) is available. The half∗ scheme is built on top of the naive 12​𝟏d12subscript1𝑑\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d} estimation as follows. The estimator finds a solution in the solution space that is closest to 12​𝟏d12subscript1𝑑\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}_{d}. In [12, Proposition 1] it is shown that

𝐗^half∗=𝐀+​𝐛′+12​(𝐈d−𝐀+​𝐀)​𝟏d.subscript^𝐗superscripthalfsuperscript𝐀superscript𝐛′12subscript𝐈𝑑superscript𝐀𝐀subscript1𝑑\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*}}=\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{b}^{\prime}+\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{I}_{d}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})\mathbf{1}_{d}. (14)

As discussed in section IV-B, although the confidence score is not available to the adversary, they manage to obtain an estimate of it via AM. Under these circumstances, to obtain an estimate of 𝐜′superscript𝐜′\mathbf{c}^{\prime}, the adversary follows the lines similar to equations (3), (4), (5) and (6). We have

=𝐜^′−𝐉𝐛a,absentsuperscript^𝐜′subscript𝐉𝐛𝑎\displaystyle=\mathbf{\hat{c}}^{\prime}-\mathbf{J}\mathbf{b}_{a}, (15)

where the subscript a𝑎a in 𝐖a,𝐛a,𝐳asubscript𝐖𝑎subscript𝐛𝑎subscript𝐳𝑎\mathbf{W}_{a},\mathbf{b}_{a},\mathbf{z}_{a} is to clarify the attribution of these parameters to AM. Noting that 𝐜^′superscript^𝐜′\mathbf{\hat{c}}^{\prime} is an estimate of 𝐜′superscript𝐜′\mathbf{c}^{\prime}, the adversary conducts agnostic inference attack using half∗ method. Denoting this estimation by 𝐗^half∗,asubscript^𝐗superscripthalf𝑎\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*},a}, we have

𝐗^half∗,asubscript^𝐗superscripthalf𝑎\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{X}}_{\textnormal{half}^{*},a} =𝐀+​(𝐜^′−𝕁​𝕎act​𝐘−𝐉𝐛)+12​(𝐈−𝐀+​𝐀)​𝟏dabsentsuperscript𝐀superscript^𝐜′𝕁subscript𝕎act𝐘𝐉𝐛12𝐈superscript𝐀𝐀subscript1𝑑\displaystyle=\mathbf{A}^{+}(\mathbf{\hat{c}}^{\prime}-\mathbb{J}\mathbb{W}_{\textnormal{act}}\mathbf{Y}-\mathbf{Jb})+\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})\mathbf{1}_{d} (16)

=\displaystyle= 1d​Tr​((𝐈−𝐀+​𝐀)​𝐊12​𝟏)+1d​Tr​(𝐀+T​𝐀+​𝐊𝐜′,𝐜^′),1𝑑Tr𝐈superscript𝐀𝐀subscript𝐊1211𝑑Trsuperscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇superscript𝐀subscript𝐊superscript𝐜′superscript^𝐜′\displaystyle\frac{1}{d}\textnormal{Tr}\left(\left(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}\right)\mathbf{K}_{\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{1}}\right)+\frac{1}{d}\textnormal{Tr}\left({\mathbf{A}^{+}}^{T}\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{c}^{\prime},\mathbf{\hat{c}}^{\prime}}\right), (21)

where the third term in (19]) is 00 due to 𝐀+T​(𝐈−𝐀+​𝐀)=𝟎superscriptsuperscript𝐀𝑇𝐈superscript𝐀𝐀0{\mathbf{A}^{+}}^{T}(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A})=\mathbf{0}. The first term in (20]) is due to [12, Theorem 2]. From (21) it is clear that the adversary’s ability to carry out agnostic inference attack is dependent on the accuracy of the estimation of a target confidence score, as reflected through the term 𝐊𝐜′,𝐜^′subscript𝐊superscript𝐜′superscript^𝐜′\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{c}^{\prime},\mathbf{\hat{c}}^{\prime}}. It is important to note that the second term in (18) is always positive, resulting in a positive value for the second term in (21). Therefore, the adversary’s performance in this scenario cannot surpass the performance obtained when the exact form of confidence scores is known. However, neither the active party nor the passive party have access to the exact form of the confidence scores or the parameters of AM, respectively, making it impossible for them to determine the exact value of (18). Despite this, we utilize (21) in section VI to obtain our numerical results when evaluating the adversary’s performance.

It is worth mentioning here that the replacement of 𝐜′superscript𝐜′\mathbf{c}^{\prime} with 𝐜′^^superscript𝐜′\hat{\mathbf{c}^{\prime}} in 6 may result in some components of the final solution falling outside of the feasible region. To handle such cases, there are multiple strategies that can be implemented, including but not limited to: i) Mapping the individual components of the solution to the closest value of 0 or 1 if they are outside of the feasible region, ii) Mapping those individual components to the value of 0.5, or iii) Mapping all the passive features to 0.5 once an estimated feature of a sample falls outside the feasible region. It is important to note that the selection of the best strategy depends on the underlying data statistics and requires deeper knowledge of the data which is indeed not available at the active party. Therefore, in order to ensure fairness in our numerical results, this paper adopts the first strategy in all datasets used in our experiments.

Remark 4.

It is worth mentioning that while half∗ was initially proposed for LR models [12], it can also be adapted for feed forward Neural Networks (NNs). This can be achieved by considering each layer of a NN as a separate LR model and applying half∗ layer by layer, until the estimate of the NN’s input is obtained. While it is possible that the results presented in this paper could be extended to NN models using this approach, we leave the confirmation of this claim for future research, where a thorough investigation of the effectiveness of half∗ in NN models is conducted.

V Privacy against agnostic inference attack

In the literature a number of algorithms have been proposed for privacy in the context of VFL in the white box setting, such as those proposed in [11, 18, 12]. The majority of these algorithms have attempted to alter the confidence scores delivered to the active party in some way. However, as demonstrated in Figure 3 and discussed in section IV, simply modifying the confidence scores is not enough to defend against agnostic inference attacks, where the adversary can build a separate classifier and improve their attack as they collect more scores from the CA. As such, it becomes clear that this approach is insufficient and leaves the passive party vulnerable to such attacks.

The central importance of the passive party’s parameters in any potential adversarial attack highlights the need for effective defense techniques that specifically target these parameters. A straightforward approach would be to implement a black box setting, in which the active party is not privy to the passive party’s parameters, 𝐖passubscript𝐖pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}. However, this approach sacrifices interpretability of the VFL model, which is a critical aspect in many applications where the client or user demands a clear explanation for the decisions made by the machine. This creates a tension between the active party, who desires a white box setting for interpretability purposes, and the passive party, who values privacy and prefers a black box setting. Therefore, there is a pressing need for a more nuanced and balanced approach to designing PPSs in the context of VFL, one that strikes a delicate balance between privacy and interpretability, and minimizes the cost of collaboration for all involved parties. The following sections present an effort towards realizing this elusive goal of balancing privacy and interpretability in VFL.

The question we aim to address is: Can a PPS be designed that creates a balance between preserving the privacy of the passive party and enabling the interpretability capabilities of the active party? To achieve this, we take into account the potential for agnostic inference attacks by an adversary using either (11) or (16) in different scenarios. Our proposed PPSs aim to systematically manipulate the parameters 𝐖passubscript𝐖pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}} in order to partially address the concerns of both parties and provide a mutually acceptable outcome.

In the following, in subsection V-A, we first review a particular case of optimization algorithms. Additionally, we provide an informal discussion on interpretability of parameters in LR. Then, in section V-B, in a case-by-case fashion, we cover the technical analysis of the proposed PPSs.

V-A Preliminaries

V-A1 Optimization problems with orthogonality constraint

Here, we provide a brief overview of an algorithm employed in this paper to determine the well-performing design parameters of one of the proposed PPSs. This algorithm is a specific instance of a larger class of optimization problems that incorporate an orthogonality constraint, specifically optimization problems over Stiefel manifolds. While this particular case is reviewed in the sequel, for a more in-depth and comprehensive understanding of the geometry of the problem and the solver algorithms, we refer the readers to [20] and [21, 22], respectively.

Consider the following optimization problem with an orthogonality constraint:

min𝐑:𝐑T​𝐑=𝐈df​(𝐑),subscript:𝐑absentsuperscript𝐑𝑇𝐑subscript𝐈𝑑𝑓𝐑\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{R}:\\ \mathbf{R}^{T}\mathbf{R}=\mathbf{I}_{d}\end{subarray}}\ \ f(\mathbf{R}), (22)

where f:ℝd×d→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} satisfies the so-called blanket assumption, i.e., the function f​(𝐑)𝑓𝐑f(\mathbf{R}) is differentiable and ∂f∂𝐑𝑓𝐑\frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{R}} is Lipschitz continuous131313Assume two metric spaces (𝓡,d𝐑)𝓡subscript𝑑𝐑(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{R}},d_{\mathbf{R}}) and (𝒳,d​x)𝒳𝑑𝑥(\mathcal{X},dx), where d𝐑subscript𝑑𝐑d_{\mathbf{R}} and d​x𝑑𝑥dx denote the metrics on 𝓡𝓡\boldsymbol{\mathcal{R}} and 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, respectively. A function f:𝓡→𝒳:𝑓→𝓡𝒳f:\boldsymbol{\mathcal{R}}\rightarrow\mathcal{X} is called Lipschitz continuous if there exists a real constant K≥0𝐾0K\geq 0, such that for all 𝐑1subscript𝐑1\mathbf{R}_{1} and 𝐑2subscript𝐑2\mathbf{R}_{2} in 𝓡𝓡\boldsymbol{\mathcal{R}}, we have dx​(f​(𝐑1),f​(𝐑2))≤K⋅d𝐑​(𝐑1,𝐑2)subscript𝑑𝑥𝑓subscript𝐑1𝑓subscript𝐑2⋅𝐾subscript𝑑𝐑subscript𝐑1subscript𝐑2d_{x}(f(\mathbf{R}_{1}),f(\mathbf{R}_{2}))\leq K\cdot d_{\mathbf{R}}(\mathbf{R}_{1},\mathbf{R}_{2}) .. The orthogonality constraint in (22) can be expressed as 𝒮d={𝐑∈ℝd×d|𝐑T​𝐑=𝐈d}subscript𝒮𝑑conditional-set𝐑superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑superscript𝐑𝑇𝐑subscript𝐈𝑑\mathcal{S}_{d}=\{\mathbf{R}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}|\mathbf{R}^{T}\mathbf{R}=\mathbf{I}_{d}\}, and is denoted as Stiefel manifold in real matrix space.

Remark 5.

The problem outlined in equation (22) plays a crucial role in various applications, such as “discretized Kohn-Sham energy minimization” and “unsupervised feature selection.” There are numerous methods available to address this problem, the majority of which utilize a trust-region strategy with quadratic approximation. However, preserving feasibility often requires the use of an orthonormalization process, which can lead to low scalability, particularly when the number of columns is substantial. Thus, it is essential to employ an efficient approach that maintains the structure of the orthogonality constraints when solving (22). In our numerical experiments, we utilize the PySTOP module, which has been implemented in Python based on the methods described in [21, 22].

Almost all the algorithms tackling problems of the type (22), require gradient of the objective function f​(𝐑)𝑓𝐑f(\mathbf{R}) wrt the set 𝒮dsubscript𝒮𝑑\mathcal{S}_{d}. Denoting this gradient by ∇sf​(𝐑)subscript∇𝑠𝑓𝐑\nabla_{s}f(\mathbf{R}), it is shown in [20, eq. (2.53)], that it is of the form

∇sf​(𝐑)=∂f∂𝐑−𝐑​(∂f∂𝐑)T​𝐑.subscript∇𝑠𝑓𝐑𝑓𝐑𝐑superscript𝑓𝐑𝑇𝐑\nabla_{s}f(\mathbf{R})=\frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{R}}-\mathbf{R}\left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{R}}\right)^{T}\mathbf{R}. (23)

One can view (23) as correcting the nominal gradient ∂f∂𝐑𝑓𝐑\frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{R}} by subtracting off its project, i.e., (∂f∂𝐑)T​𝐑superscript𝑓𝐑𝑇𝐑(\frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{R}})^{T}\mathbf{R} onto the current solution 𝐑𝐑\mathbf{R}. This ensures that the corrected gradient ∇sf​(𝐑)subscript∇𝑠𝑓𝐑\nabla_{s}f(\mathbf{R}) is tangent to the manifold.

In the following, we provide an analytically tractable example of this optimization (22) in the context of PPSs in VFL. As it will be elaborated later in section V-B, providing analytical solutions for more interesting problems are still open if not infeasible. Therefore, in such cases we resort to iterative solver algorithms.

Example 1.

To that end, the passive parameters 𝐖passubscript𝐖pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}} are transformed via a secret orthonormal matrix 𝐑𝐑\mathbf{R} (𝐑T​𝐑=𝐈superscript𝐑𝑇𝐑𝐈\mathbf{R}^{T}\mathbf{R}=\mathbf{I}), and it is the transformed version 𝐖pas​𝐑subscript𝐖pas𝐑\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}\mathbf{R} which is revealed to the active party. Remark 6.

A similar problem has been considered in [12, Theorem 3], where instead of transforming the parameters, the passive party transforms the features. In that study, the proof approach relies on Von Neumann’s trace inequality, which can serve as an alternative to the optimization over Stiefel manifolds discussed in this paper. However, as will be made evident in the following sections, the optimization over Stiefel manifolds has a distinct advantage in that it allows for the treatment of a wide range of more complex problems through the use of iterative algorithms.

Remark 7.

It is worth noting that the example discussed in this section has a couple of limitations. Firstly, the assumption that the adversary will use the least square method is unrealistic as there are other inference attack methods that are more advanced and efficient. Secondly, transforming the parameter or feature space, as discussed in [12, Theorem 3, Remark 6]), results in a significant and uncontrolled distortion of the parameters. This can make it difficult for the active party to interpret the results of the VFL model, and may even obstruct their ability to justify the outcomes in certain circumstances. For example, in the Bank-FinTech scenario, the bank may be required to provide a justification for rejecting a customer’s credit card application. Thus, it is crucial that these limitations are taken into consideration when designing any PPS so as to ensure the active party’s concerns are addressed.

V-A2 Interpretability of the VFL model at the active party

The widespread adoption of machine learning-based automation systems in various sectors of society, including governments, banking, healthcare, and education, has become increasingly common. Although these systems bring many operational benefits, there are also important challenges that need to be addressed. One such challenge in the context of VFL is the interpretability of machine-based decisions when passive parties participate in the training of VFL using PPSs. This becomes particularly relevant in cases where VFL models are used to make decisions that have legal, insurance, or health implications, as a lack of justifiability of the outcomes can potentially harm the trust relationship between users and the system.

Interpretability is an essential aspect of machine learning models and refers to the ability to understand the relationship between the parameters of the model and its outcomes. Simple machine learning models such as linear and logistic regression, decision trees, and Lasso/Ridge regression are generally preferred over more complex deep learning models when performance levels are comparable, as they offer greater interpretability. For example, in the case of logistic regression, the odds ratio of two different classes for a sample can be easily calculated as e(𝐰i−𝐰j)​𝐱1superscript𝑒subscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝐰𝑗subscript𝐱1e^{(\mathbf{w}_{i}-\mathbf{w}_{j})\mathbf{x}_{1}}, where 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i} is the i𝑖i-th row of the parameter matrix [𝐖act,𝐖pas]subscript𝐖actsubscript𝐖pas[\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{act}},\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}]. Consider the Bank-FinTech example, where two customers 𝐱1subscript𝐱1\mathbf{x}_{1} and 𝐱2subscript𝐱2\mathbf{x}_{2} have similar active features but different passive features and one of them is approved for a credit card application while the other is rejected. If the customer 𝐱1subscript𝐱1\mathbf{x}_{1} objects to the rejection, the bank must be able to justify the decision based on the difference in the passive feature and the corresponding change in the odds ratio, e(w​i,dt−w​j,dt)​(x1,dt−x2,dt)superscript𝑒𝑤𝑖subscript𝑑𝑡𝑤𝑗subscript𝑑𝑡subscript𝑥1subscript𝑑𝑡subscript𝑥2subscript𝑑𝑡e^{(w{i,d_{t}}-w{j,d_{t}})(x_{1,d_{t}}-x_{2,d_{t}})}, where the subscript dtsubscript𝑑𝑡d_{t} refers to the index of the passive feature.

V-B Privacy-preserving schemes

When evaluating the effectiveness of agnostic inference attacks, we take a “genie-aided” approach in which the adversary is given the exact form of the confidence scores. This is because the performance of the agnostic inference attacks in (13) and (21) is heavily dependent on the matrix 𝐊𝐜,𝐜^′subscript𝐊𝐜superscript^𝐜′\mathbf{K}_{\mathbf{c},\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}}. Since the passive party does not have access to 𝐜^′superscript^𝐜′\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime}, it is impossible to make accurate calculations based on it. By assuming a genie-aided scenario, we acknowledge that the adversary may have the resources and capacity (whether through their own data and computational power or through collusion/collaboration with some data owners as per [11]) to estimate 𝐜^′superscript^𝐜′\hat{\mathbf{c}}^{\prime} accurately. Thus, our goal is to diminish the adversary’s best-case attack performance under these circumstances. It is therefore in the benefit of the passive party to design privacy-preserving techniques based on the availability of 𝐜′superscript𝐜′\mathbf{c}^{\prime} at the active party in order to maximize privacy protection.

In designing the proposed PPSs, our goal is to additionally keep the the passive parameters as much interpretable as possible. To that end, we consider the function

g=1d​kTr((𝐖pas−𝐖n)T(𝐖pas−𝐖n)g=\frac{1}{dk}\textnormal{Tr}((\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}-\mathbf{W}_{n})^{T}(\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}-\mathbf{W}_{n}) (33)

as a measure of distance between 𝐖nsubscript𝐖𝑛\mathbf{W}_{n} and 𝐖passubscript𝐖pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}, where 𝐖nsubscript𝐖𝑛\mathbf{W}_{n} is the parameter set the active party is given access to instead of 𝐖passubscript𝐖pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}171717The function g𝑔g will take different arguments in the sequel depending of what mapping is considered from 𝐖passubscript𝐖pas\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}} to 𝐖nsubscript𝐖𝑛\mathbf{W}_{n} ..

We study the PPSs in four different cases: For the cases i) d≥k𝑑𝑘d\geq k, ii) 1<d<k1𝑑𝑘1<d<k we propose a heuristic approach which is based on transforming the passive parameters via orthonormal matrices, whereas in cases iii) d=1𝑑1d=1 and iv) k=2,d>1formulae-sequence𝑘2𝑑1k=2,d>1 we try to approach the general problem where there is no particular assumption on the type of the mapping from passive parameters to the ones given to the active party.

V-B1 Case d≥k𝑑𝑘d\geq k

Remark 8.

Note that the way the adversary obtains a system of linear equations in (6) is not unique, however, all of these linear systems can be expressed similar to (6) via 𝐉new=𝐓𝐉subscript𝐉new𝐓𝐉\mathbf{J}_{\textnormal{new}}=\mathbf{TJ} with 𝐓(k−1)×(k−1)subscript𝐓𝑘1𝑘1\mathbf{T}_{(k-1)\times(k-1)} being an invertible matrix, (secretly) used by the adversary. From this standpoint, it is critical that regardless of the choice of 𝐓𝐓\mathbf{T}, the MSE in (38) on which the optimization in (39) is performed is the same MSE that the adversary experiences. Therefore, any proposed/designed privacy-preserving scheme should be independent of any transformation matrix 𝐓𝐓\mathbf{T} used by the adversary, as otherwise, intended privacy (certain MSE) and interpretaibility (g​(𝐑)=ϵ𝑔𝐑italic-ϵg(\mathbf{R})=\epsilon) concerns are not guaranteed. From the objective function in (39), independence of g​(𝐑)𝑔𝐑g(\mathbf{R}) is obvious. For the function fhalf∗,aPPS​(𝐑)superscriptsubscript𝑓superscripthalf𝑎PPS𝐑f_{\textnormal{half}^{*},a}^{\textnormal{PPS}}(\mathbf{R}), note that the dependency on 𝐉𝐉\mathbf{J} is via 𝐀+​𝐀superscript𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}. Hence, if the adversary forms a new matrix 𝐀new=Jnew​𝐖pas=𝐓𝐉𝐖passubscript𝐀newsubscript𝐽newsubscript𝐖passubscript𝐓𝐉𝐖pas\mathbf{A}_{\textnormal{new}}=J_{\textnormal{new}}\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}=\mathbf{TJ}\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}, we have

𝐀new+​𝐀newsubscriptsuperscript𝐀newsubscript𝐀new\displaystyle\mathbf{A}^{+}_{\textnormal{new}}\mathbf{A}_{\textnormal{new}} =(𝐉new​𝐖pas)+​(𝐉new​𝐖pas)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐉newsubscript𝐖passubscript𝐉newsubscript𝐖pas\displaystyle=(\mathbf{J}_{\textnormal{new}}\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}})^{+}(\mathbf{J}_{\textnormal{new}}\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}})
=(𝐓𝐉𝐖pas)+​(𝐓𝐉𝐖pas)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐓𝐉𝐖passubscript𝐓𝐉𝐖pas\displaystyle=(\mathbf{TJ}\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}})^{+}(\mathbf{TJ}\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}})
=(𝐉𝐖pas)+​𝐓−1​𝐓​(𝐉𝐖pas)=𝐀+​𝐀.absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐉𝐖passuperscript𝐓1𝐓subscript𝐉𝐖passuperscript𝐀𝐀\displaystyle=(\mathbf{J}\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}})^{+}\mathbf{T}^{-1}\mathbf{T}(\mathbf{JW}_{\textnormal{pas}})=\mathbf{A}^{+}\mathbf{A}.

Therefore, the solution of the objective function is independent of any orthogonal transformation of 𝐉𝐉\mathbf{J}.

If the blanket assumption is satisfied on the objective of the problem in (39), it fits within the category of the optimization problems reviewed in section V-A. Continuity is obvious. The following proposition ascertains the Lipschitz continuity.

Proposition 1.

The objective function in (39) is Lipschitz continuous.

Proof.

Proof of the proposition follows by noting that the sum of two Lipschitz continuous functions is Lipschitz continuous. ∎

Remark 9.

The privacy-preserving scheme proposed in this case is based on the half∗ estimation method. The reason for choosing this method is that designing a defense mechanism against one of the most powerful inference attack techniques would likely have a negative impact on the performance of other attack techniques. The exact impact on the performance of other techniques has not been analyzed in this study. We leave the technical analysis of this matter for interested researchers.

V-B2 Case 1<d<k1𝑑𝑘1<d<k

Recall that this is a case of an overdetermined system, where a unique solution is obtained when the adversary have all the parameters in (5). Otherwise an approximate solution is obtained. Following similar steps as in the previous case, and noting that the adversary uses 𝐖n=𝐖pas​𝐑subscript𝐖𝑛subscript𝐖pas𝐑\mathbf{W}_{n}=\mathbf{W}_{\textnormal{pas}}\mathbf{R} for their attack, the resulting MSE reads as

By obtaining the Stiefel gradient of (47), and following the similar steps provided in the example of section V-A1, it is easy to verify that when no interpretability constraint is in place, the best transformation matrix is 𝐑=−𝐈𝐑𝐈\mathbf{R}=-\mathbf{I}. That is, the passive party change the sign of their parameters. To incorporate the active party’s interpretability concerns as well, we form the following optimization problem

min𝐑:𝐑∈𝒮d2d​Tr​(𝐑𝐊0)+λ​(g​(𝐑)−ϵ)2.subscript:𝐑𝐑subscript𝒮𝑑2𝑑Trsubscript𝐑𝐊0𝜆superscript𝑔𝐑italic-ϵ2\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{R}:\mathbf{R}\in\mathcal{S}_{d}\end{subarray}}\ \ \frac{2}{d}\textnormal{Tr}(\mathbf{R}\mathbf{K}_{0})+\lambda\left(g(\mathbf{R})-\epsilon\right)^{2}. (48)

It is obvious that the problem in (48) satisfies the blanket assumption.

Remark 10.

It is important to note that when the active party has no privacy concerns, it would be clear to them that the transformation matrix is 𝐑=−𝐈𝐑𝐈\mathbf{R}=-\mathbf{I}. However, a dishonest active party may as well pretend that they have no interest in the interpretation of the results. In either case, they could easily recover the passive party’s features by changing the sign of the parameters. One potential solution to address this issue is to keep the active party uncertain about whether 𝐑=𝐈𝐑𝐈\mathbf{R}=\mathbf{I} or 𝐑=−𝐈𝐑𝐈\mathbf{R}=-\mathbf{I} was used for the parameter mapping. In this scenario, even if the adversary takes the average of the estimations obtained from both cases, the convexity of MSE would prevent them from obtaining an estimation error lower than the average of the MSE in each case. Another approach to preserving privacy would be to choose a random value for ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and transform the parameters accordingly without revealing the value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon to the active party.

Remark 11.

For the special case of d=1,k=2formulae-sequence𝑑1𝑘2d=1,k=2, it can be easily verified that given the vectors 𝐰n=[w1​n,w2​n]subscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝑤1𝑛subscript𝑤2𝑛\mathbf{w}_{n}=[w_{1n},w_{2n}] and 𝐰pas=[w1,w2]subscript𝐰passubscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}}=[w_{1},w_{2}], we have

MSE​(x^LS,aPPS)MSEsuperscriptsubscript^𝑥LS𝑎PPS\displaystyle\textnormal{MSE}(\hat{x}_{\textnormal{LS},a}^{\textnormal{PPS}}) =σ2​(wn​1−w1+w2−w2​nw1​n−w2​n)2.absentsuperscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑛1subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2subscript𝑤2𝑛subscript𝑤1𝑛subscript𝑤2𝑛2\displaystyle=\sigma^{2}\left(\frac{w_{n1}-w_{1}+w_{2}-w_{2n}}{w_{1n}-w_{2n}}\right)^{2}. (51)

Due to the equality constraint, i.e., r=2​ϵ𝑟2italic-ϵr=\sqrt{2\epsilon}, the optimization is on a circle with the only variable θ𝜃\theta. By differentiating the objective in (52) wrt θ𝜃\theta, it is verified that the necessary condition for the maximum value is θ∈{3​π4,7​π4}𝜃3𝜋47𝜋4\theta\in\{\frac{3\pi}{4},\frac{7\pi}{4}\}. As a result, the maximiser of (50) is in the form of 𝐰n=[𝐰pas−ϵ,𝐰pas+ϵ]subscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐰pasitalic-ϵsubscript𝐰pasitalic-ϵ\mathbf{w}_{n}=[\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}}-\sqrt{\epsilon},\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}}+\sqrt{\epsilon}] or [𝐰pas+ϵ,𝐰pas−ϵ]subscript𝐰pasitalic-ϵsubscript𝐰pasitalic-ϵ[\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}}+\sqrt{\epsilon},\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}}-\sqrt{\epsilon}]. The designer can try both and choose the one which maximises (49) the most. Observe from section V-A2, that the interpretability is not affected if both of the parameters are shifted in the same direction. This is also easy to verity from (51) in which case results in zero MSE. Note that the same approach in this Remark can be used to convert the problem in (50) into an optimization over an n-Sphere with a fixed radius (due to the equality constraint). This would eliminate one variable and convert the problem to an unconstrained optimization over the surface an n-Sphere which could speed up the optimization process.

Remark 12.

The problem in (50) is a simple vector-based optimization problem which is solved using algorithms, such as “trust-region constrained” or “sequential least squares programming”. In our numerical experiments, we use the former using Scipy package in python. Observe that when the equality constraint in (50) is replaced with inequality, and for larger values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, there can be possibly an infinite number of solutions for (50) that result in 𝐀nT​𝐀n=𝐰𝐧𝐓​𝐉𝐓​𝐉𝐰𝐧=0superscriptsubscript𝐀𝑛𝑇subscript𝐀𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝐧𝐓superscript𝐉𝐓subscript𝐉𝐰𝐧0\mathbf{A}_{n}^{T}\mathbf{A}_{n}=\mathbf{\mathbf{w}_{n}^{T}\mathbf{J}^{T}\mathbf{J}\mathbf{w_{n}}}=0. This could be the case for vectors with equal components that are in the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-vicinity of 𝐰passubscript𝐰pas\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}}. Considering equality constraint, significantly affects the demanding task of discarding such solutions.

Remark 13.

An interesting observation here is that, in the case of d=1𝑑1d=1, the PPS does not depend on the statistics of the data. This rather undermines the idea of preserving passive party’s privacy as the active party can easily follow the same steps to solve (50). To overcome this situation, guidelines provided in Remark 10 could be applied. That is, either the passive party will not remain honest in revealing whether a PPS is in place, or they choose a random and secret 0≤ϵ′≤ϵ0superscriptitalic-ϵ′italic-ϵ0\leq\epsilon^{\prime}\leq\epsilon.

Remark 14.

In this scenario, any transformation of the parameters similar to previous cases (𝐑∈ℝ𝐑ℝ\mathbf{R}\in\mathbb{R} is a scalar) would result in scaling all the parameters by a constant factor, meaning 𝐰n=r​𝐰passubscript𝐰𝑛𝑟subscript𝐰pas\mathbf{w}_{n}=r\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}}. This ensures that the system of equations established by the adversary remains as an overdetermined system with a unique solution. Consequently, no matter which component of 𝐰nsubscript𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}_{n} the adversary selects, the attack equation would take the form wn,i​x=r​wpas,i​x=bi′subscript𝑤𝑛𝑖𝑥𝑟subscript𝑤pas,i𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′w_{n,i}x=rw_{\textnormal{pas,i}}x=b_{i}^{\prime}, where wn,isubscript𝑤𝑛𝑖w_{n,i}, wpas, isubscript𝑤pas, iw_{\textnormal{pas, i}} and bi′superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖′b_{i}^{\prime} are the i𝑖i-th components of 𝐰nsubscript𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}_{n}, 𝐰passubscript𝐰pas\mathbf{w}_{\textnormal{pas}} and 𝐛′superscript𝐛′\mathbf{b}^{\prime}, respectively. It is obvious that, in this case, not only a fixed scaling but any linear transformation of the parameters (which results in an overdetermined system with no solution) cannot keep the parameters secret indefinitely. As discussed in [12, section VI], the active party can collect valuable statistical information from received confidence scores (if the exact forms are provided) over time, which could be used to estimate the actual values of the parameters.

Remark 15.

The optimization problems in (50) and (54) for d=1𝑑1d=1 and k=2𝑘2k=2, respectively, are more general compared to the transforming matrices proposed in cases i and ii. However, the implementation of the pseudo-inverse of a matrix is technically challenging, which restricts the extension of these cases to cases i and ii. Nevertheless, these approaches not only offer the potential to find better solutions when they are feasible, but also provide valuable insights into how far the designs proposed for cases i and ii are from the more general solutions (when both cases are applicable on a dataset).
